3574 /* =============================================================== 3575 * 3576 * FONT 3577 * 3578 * ===============================================================*/ 3579 /* Font handling in this library was designed to be quite customizable and lets 3580 you decide what you want to use and what you want to provide. There are three 3581 different ways to use the font atlas. The first two will use your font 3582 handling scheme and only requires essential data to run nuklear. The next 3583 slightly more advanced features is font handling with vertex buffer output. 3584 Finally the most complex API wise is using nuklear's font baking API. 3585 3586 1.) Using your own implementation without vertex buffer output 3587 -------------------------------------------------------------- 3588 So first up the easiest way to do font handling is by just providing a 3589 `nk_user_font` struct which only requires the height in pixel of the used 3590 font and a callback to calculate the width of a string. This way of handling 3591 fonts is best fitted for using the normal draw shape command API where you 3592 do all the text drawing yourself and the library does not require any kind 3593 of deeper knowledge about which font handling mechanism you use. 3594 IMPORTANT: the `nk_user_font` pointer provided to nuklear has to persist 3595 over the complete life time! I know this sucks but it is currently the only 3596 way to switch between fonts. 3597 3598 float your_text_width_calculation(nk_handle handle, float height, const char *text, int len) 3599 { 3600 your_font_type *type = handle.ptr; 3601 float text_width = ...; 3602 return text_width; 3603 } 3604 3605 struct nk_user_font font; 3606 font.userdata.ptr = &your_font_class_or_struct; 3607 font.height = your_font_height; 3608 font.width = your_text_width_calculation; 3609 3610 struct nk_context ctx; 3611 nk_init_default(&ctx, &font); 3612 3613 2.) Using your own implementation with vertex buffer output 3614 -------------------------------------------------------------- 3615 While the first approach works fine if you don't want to use the optional 3616 vertex buffer output it is not enough if you do. To get font handling working 3617 for these cases you have to provide two additional parameters inside the 3618 `nk_user_font`. First a texture atlas handle used to draw text as subimages 3619 of a bigger font atlas texture and a callback to query a character's glyph 3620 information (offset, size, ...). So it is still possible to provide your own 3621 font and use the vertex buffer output. 3622 3623 float your_text_width_calculation(nk_handle handle, float height, const char *text, int len) 3624 { 3625 your_font_type *type = handle.ptr; 3626 float text_width = ...; 3627 return text_width; 3628 } 3629 void query_your_font_glyph(nk_handle handle, float font_height, struct nk_user_font_glyph *glyph, nk_rune codepoint, nk_rune next_codepoint) 3630 { 3631 your_font_type *type = handle.ptr; 3632 glyph.width = ...; 3633 glyph.height = ...; 3634 glyph.xadvance = ...; 3635 glyph.uv[0].x = ...; 3636 glyph.uv[0].y = ...; 3637 glyph.uv[1].x = ...; 3638 glyph.uv[1].y = ...; 3639 glyph.offset.x = ...; 3640 glyph.offset.y = ...; 3641 } 3642 3643 struct nk_user_font font; 3644 font.userdata.ptr = &your_font_class_or_struct; 3645 font.height = your_font_height; 3646 font.width = your_text_width_calculation; 3647 font.query = query_your_font_glyph; 3648 font.texture.id = your_font_texture; 3649 3650 struct nk_context ctx; 3651 nk_init_default(&ctx, &font); 3652 3653 3.) Nuklear font baker 3654 ------------------------------------ 3655 The final approach if you do not have a font handling functionality or don't 3656 want to use it in this library is by using the optional font baker. 3657 The font baker APIs can be used to create a font plus font atlas texture 3658 and can be used with or without the vertex buffer output. 3659 3660 It still uses the `nk_user_font` struct and the two different approaches 3661 previously stated still work. The font baker is not located inside 3662 `nk_context` like all other systems since it can be understood as more of 3663 an extension to nuklear and does not really depend on any `nk_context` state. 3664 3665 Font baker need to be initialized first by one of the nk_font_atlas_init_xxx 3666 functions. If you don't care about memory just call the default version 3667 `nk_font_atlas_init_default` which will allocate all memory from the standard library. 3668 If you want to control memory allocation but you don't care if the allocated 3669 memory is temporary and therefore can be freed directly after the baking process 3670 is over or permanent you can call `nk_font_atlas_init`. 3671 3672 After successfully initializing the font baker you can add Truetype(.ttf) fonts from 3673 different sources like memory or from file by calling one of the `nk_font_atlas_add_xxx`. 3674 functions. Adding font will permanently store each font, font config and ttf memory block(!) 3675 inside the font atlas and allows to reuse the font atlas. If you don't want to reuse 3676 the font baker by for example adding additional fonts you can call 3677 `nk_font_atlas_cleanup` after the baking process is over (after calling nk_font_atlas_end). 3678 3679 As soon as you added all fonts you wanted you can now start the baking process 3680 for every selected glyph to image by calling `nk_font_atlas_bake`. 3681 The baking process returns image memory, width and height which can be used to 3682 either create your own image object or upload it to any graphics library. 3683 No matter which case you finally have to call `nk_font_atlas_end` which 3684 will free all temporary memory including the font atlas image so make sure 3685 you created our texture beforehand. `nk_font_atlas_end` requires a handle 3686 to your font texture or object and optionally fills a `struct nk_draw_null_texture` 3687 which can be used for the optional vertex output. If you don't want it just 3688 set the argument to `NULL`. 3689 3690 At this point you are done and if you don't want to reuse the font atlas you 3691 can call `nk_font_atlas_cleanup` to free all truetype blobs and configuration 3692 memory. Finally if you don't use the font atlas and any of it's fonts anymore 3693 you need to call `nk_font_atlas_clear` to free all memory still being used. 3694 3695 struct nk_font_atlas atlas; 3696 nk_font_atlas_init_default(&atlas); 3697 nk_font_atlas_begin(&atlas); 3698 nk_font *font = nk_font_atlas_add_from_file(&atlas, "Path/To/Your/TTF_Font.ttf", 13, 0); 3699 nk_font *font2 = nk_font_atlas_add_from_file(&atlas, "Path/To/Your/TTF_Font2.ttf", 16, 0); 3700 const void* img = nk_font_atlas_bake(&atlas, &img_width, &img_height, NK_FONT_ATLAS_RGBA32); 3701 nk_font_atlas_end(&atlas, nk_handle_id(texture), 0); 3702 3703 struct nk_context ctx; 3704 nk_init_default(&ctx, &font->handle); 3705 while (1) { 3706 3707 } 3708 nk_font_atlas_clear(&atlas); 3709 3710 The font baker API is probably the most complex API inside this library and 3711 I would suggest reading some of my examples `example/` to get a grip on how 3712 to use the font atlas. There are a number of details I left out. For example 3713 how to merge fonts, configure a font with `nk_font_config` to use other languages, 3714 use another texture coordinate format and a lot more: 3715 3716 struct nk_font_config cfg = nk_font_config(font_pixel_height); In this case all control lies in the hand of the user 3902 since he can exactly control where the memory comes from and how much memory 3903 the library should consume. Of course using the fixed size API removes the 3904 ability to automatically resize a buffer if not enough memory is provided so 3905 you have to take over the resizing. While being a fixed sized buffer sounds 3906 quite limiting, it is very effective in this library since the actual memory 3907 consumption is quite stable and has a fixed upper bound for a lot of cases. 3908 3909 If you don't want to think about how much memory the library should allocate 3910 at all time or have a very dynamic UI with unpredictable memory consumption 3911 habits but still want control over memory allocation you can use the dynamic 3912 allocator based API.
